abstract.text: This article describes the essential parts of KeyboardKit.

inlineContent.text: This article describes essential types, models, and views that KeyboardKit provides. See the
guide for information on how to set up your main app and keyboard extension for KeyboardKit.
unlocks a lot of additional, essential Pro features. Information about Pro features can be found further down.
KeyboardKit uses namespaces nest types into logical groups, like
, etc. This helps making the library surface smaller and easier to navigate.
Namespaces don’t contain protocols or important types that are meant to be exposed as top-level types. This includes important types like
, etc., and important views, like
The
namespace contains many essential, keyboard-related types and views. By typing
and
, Xcode will list all types in this namespace, like
, etc.
The
namespace contains many essential, keyboard-related models that are used by many library features, for instance:
Many of these models, like
, could be considered to belong in other namespaces, but are placed in
since they describe essential parts of the keyboard.
is the most essential type in the library. See the
guide on how to use it to access a bunch of additional
, and lifecycle functions like
You can override controller functions to customize its behavior. By delegating the responsibility of certain operations to its
and
, you can avoid having to rely on the controller for most operations.
KeyboardKit also has a
that aims to make it easier to use KeyboardKit in platforms that don’t support UIKit.
KeyboardKit has a
that provides observable keyboard state. It has a
reference, lets you get and set
, etc. and also has auto-persisted
Other namespaces define separate contexts, like
, etc. They all update the keyboard view when they’re modified, and provide namespace-specific properties and settings.
KeyboardKit automatically creates instances of these classes and injects them into
, and syncs with the controller when needed.
KeyboardKit has a
-specific
type with auto-persisted keyboard settings. It has a global
that is shared by all settings types and used to persist settings.
The
property is used as the standard settings instance in KeyboardKit, as are the other contexts. If you set up KeyboardKit with a
that defines an App Group, this store will sync data between the app and its keyboard.
properties use the store that’s available when they’re first accessed. Make sure to set up a custom store BEFORE accessing any of these settings properties.
KeyboardKit has a
protocol that can be used to define the keyboard’s behavior. It’s used by some services, like the standard
, to make behavior-based decisions.
KeyboardKit automatically creates an instance of
and injects it into
. You can replace it at any time, by implementing the procotol from scratch or by inheriting and customizing the standard behavior.
KeyboardKit extends native types like
and
with more functionality. See the extension section in documentation root article for more info.
KeyboardKit has a
that mimics the native iOS keyboard. It can be used for alphabetic, numeric & symbolic keyboards, supports all supported locales, layouts, callouts, etc., and can be used on all Apple platforms:
This component is so important, that it has a dedicated
article that describes how to use and customize it.
The
namespace has a lot of other standard views, styles, and view-related types to make it easy to build great keyboards.
The
namespace has
views & styles that can be used to mimic all parts of a native keyboard.
A
renders the full button, while other views like
(not shown here) renders parts of it.
A
can be used if
is enabled, to show a compact toolbar.
The
has a
view builder that lets you specify which view to use as collapsed content.
KeyboardKit Pro automatically detects when an external keyboard is connected, and update this state accordingly.
The
can be used to switch to the next keyboard on tap and to show a keyboard menu on long press.
The
will automatically render a next keyboard switcher for the
action.
The
mimics a native number pad, which can be used for pure numeric inputs.
will automatically use this view for the
keyboard type.
The keyboard
applies a minimum height to its content.
The
always renders a toolbar by default, to avoid callouts from being cut off.
You
can
to remove the toolbar, but it’s not recommended, since a custom keyboard can’t render content outside of its frame.
Most
views have a style view modifier. You can e.g. apply an
to
to customize the autocomplete toolbar style, and
to customize the button style.
unlocks additional, powerful
capabilities, including full support for all
locales, a full-blown
, input toolbars, powerful
s, etc.
KeyboardKit Pro unlocks additional
-related views and utilities, that make it easier to create even more powerful keyboards:
KeyboardKit Pro unlocks localized services for all
locales. This lets you create fully localized keyboards that automatically use correct buttons, autocomplete & callouts.
The various license tiers unlock different amount of locales, where Gold unlocks all. See the
article for more information.
KeyboardKit Pro unlocks an
that is added to
when a valid license is registered.
The emoji keyboard has support for categories, runtime version adjustments and skintones. Read more in the
article.
KeyboardKit Pro will automatically add an additional input toolbar above
on large iPads, to fit the native keyboard.
You can apply
to the keyboard view to set whether to show or hide the toolbar, or to customize its buttons.
The
can be used to toggle between two toolbars, e.g. to place a main menu “behind” the autocomplete toolbar.
This view wraps itself in a
, which means that it can also be styled with the
modifier.
The keyboard
renders a bottom keyboard row with the same behavior as a full
. It can be used when you want to replace the rows above with a custom user interface.
KeyboardKit Pro also unlocks
-related previews, that can be used to preview
and
for various configurations, locales, styles, themes, etc.
KeyboardKit Pro unlocks a
that can be used to preview a
for various locales, styles, etc.
This preview is intended to be used in the main app, for instance to show the effect of changing settings or styles.
Note that this view renders a full keyboard, so it’s not performant enough to preview many keyboards at once. For these cases, use a
instead.
KeyboardKit Pro unlocks a
that can be used to preview a
This preview is intended to be used in the main app, for instance to list themes in a picker.
This view is more performant than
See the
article for more information.
KeyboardKit makes it super simple to customize or replace the standard
. The
guide has information that shows you how to do this with just a few lines of code.
While
will render most
s, some don’t have a standard visual representation. For instance setting the main
to
has no effect if you use the standard
You can add support for unsupported keyboard types by creating a custom keyboard view that renders the standard
(or a customized one) for supported keyboard types, and custom views for other types, for instance:

code: /// Passed in from the controller for convenience

inlineContent.text: You can add a
action item to your keyboard to automatically switch to your custom keyboard when its tapped.
You can implement a custom
with the
type builder, then handle it by checking if the main
matches your custom type:
You can render a custom type just like you would any of the unsupported keyboard types, as demonstrated in the previous paragraph.

abstract.text: Whether the keyboard is collapsed.
A custom keyboard type, if you need to use one.
Keyboard-specific state.
This enum defines supported space drag sensitivities.

keyboard extensions.

can customize the button style of any action.

define keyboard-specific behaviors.
This view can be used to mimic a native iOS keyboard.
An image keyboard, not currently implemented.
This enum defines various keyboard return key types.
This type can be used to define important properties for
your app, and is also a namespace for app-based features.
This view creates a keyboard bottom row with leading
and trailing actions around a space key.
This class defines the standard keyboard behavior of
a standard western keyboard, with some locale tweaks.
The text document proxy that is currently active.
This enum defines various keyboard types for various
kinds of inputs.
This view can be used to render a collapsed keyboard,
e.g. when an external keyboard is connected.
The store that will be used by library settings.

Triggers the system keyboard switcher on release and long press.
This view can be used to toggle between two toolbars.
KeyboardKit helps you create fully customizable keyboard extensions, using Swift and SwiftUI.

diacritic variant.

the
component.

value.

for the core keyboard functionality.

and how to use and configure it.

component.

The keyboard type that is currently used.
A list of KeyboardKit supported locales.
The current locale, by default
This enum defines various input toolbar modes, which
can be used to set how an input toolbar is displayed.
This type is used for essential keyboard settings.
This view can be used to create keyboard buttons for
various keyboard actions.
This protocol can be implemented by any classes that can
handle triggered
events.
This protocol can be implemented by any classes that can
be used to control a keyboard extension.
This enum defines various keyboard shift states.
This type defines the full set of keys on a keyboard and
is also a namespace for layout-related types.
This function is called when the controller is about
to create or update the keyboard view.
This context has observable callout-related state and is
used for both input and action callouts.
This class has observable states and persistent settings
for keyboard autocomplete.

with various actions, themes and services.
This enum defines various space long press behaviors.
This enum defines keyboard auto-capitalization types.

switcher button, which switches to the next keyboard
when tapped, and opens a switcher menu on long press.
